previous_headings: Required user inputs
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: order estimate ATSM package, user needs specify several general inputs, namely: 1. Desired ATSM class Model type: character vector indicating model type estimated, presented Table @ref(tab:ModFea). 2. Risk factor set Economies: character vector containing names economies included system; Global variables: character vector containing labels desired global unspanned factors used model estimation; Domestic variables: character vector containing labels desired domestic unspanned factors used model estimation; Number spanned factors (N): scalar represents number country-specific spanned factors. Note N equal across countries. 3. Sample span Initial sample date: Start date sample period format “dd-mm-yyyy”; End sample date: End date sample period format “dd-mm-yyyy”. 4. Frequency data: character vector specifies frequency time series data. available options : “Annually”, “Quarterly”, “Monthly”, “Weekly”, “Daily Business Days”, “Daily Days”. 5. Stationary constraint QQ-dynamics: binary variable equals 11 user wishes impose constraint largest eigenvalue QQ-measure strictly less 11 otherwise, set 00. enforcing stationary constraint may prolong model estimation, can improve convergence model. 6. Selected folder save outputs Path selected graphical outputs saved. set NULL, outputs stored user’s temporary directory (accessible via tempdir()). 7. Output label Character vector length one, specifying name used file stores model outputs. One possible example basic model inputs
code: # 1) Model type ModelType <- "JPS original"  # 2) Risk factor set Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") GlobalVar <- c("GBC", "CPI_OECD") # Global variables DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") # Domestic variables  N <- 3 # number of spanned factors per country  # 3) Sample span Initial_Date <- "01-05-2005" # Format: "dd-mm-yyyy" Final_Date <- "01-12-2019" # Format: "dd-mm-yyyy"  # 4) Frequency of the data DataFrequency <- "Monthly"  # 5) Risk-neutral stationary constraint StationarityUnderQ <- 0 # 1 = set stationary condition under the Q; 0 = no stationary condition  # 6) Path to save outputs Folder2Save <- NULL  # 7) Output label OutputLabel <- "Model_demo"

text: influential paper, Bauer, Rudebusch, Wu (2012) (BRW, 2012) shown estimates traditional ATSMs can severely biased due typical small-sample size used studies. result, models may produce unreasonably stable expected future short-term interest, therefore distorting term premia estimates long-maturity bonds. circumvent problem, propose bootstrap-based method relies indirect inference estimation corrects bias present previous works. version 0.3.10.3.1, MultiATSM package accommodates framework proposed BRW (2012) one ATSM types. additional inputs must specified, user intends perform model estimation along lines BRW (2012). : Mean median P-dynamics estimates (Cent_Measure): user must decide whether compute mean median physical dynamics estimates bootstrap iteration. compute mean (median), user must set Mean (Median); Adjustment parameter (gamma): parameter controls degree shrinkage difference OLS estimates BRW (2012)’s bootstrap-based one iteration. value parameter fixed must lie interval ]0;1[]0;1[; Number iteration (N_iter) : total amount iterations used stochastic approximation algorithm burn-; Number bootstrap samples (B): quantity simulated samples used burn-actual iteration; Perform closeness check (checkBRW): flag whether user wishes check root mean square distance model estimates produced bias-correction method generated OLS. Default set TRUE; Number bootstrap samples used closeness check (B_check): default set 100,000; Number burn-iteration (N_burn): quantity iterations discarded first stage bias-correction estimation process. recommended number 15%15\% total number iterations. Eigenvalue restriction (Eigen_rest): set restriction largest eigenvalue PP-measure. Default 11.
code: BRWlist <- within(list(Cent_Measure = "Mean", gamma = 0.2, N_iter = 500, B = 50,                         checkBRW = TRUE, B_check = 1000, Eigen_rest = 1), N_burn <- round(N_iter * 0.15))

title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: current form, MultiATSM package allows calculation two risk compensation measures: term premia forward premia. particular, nn-maturity bond yield can decomposed sum expected short-rate (Expt(n)Exp_t^{(n)}) term premia (TPt(n)TP_t^{(n)}) components. Technically: yt(n)=Expt(n)+TPt(n) y_t^{(n)} = Exp_t^{(n)} + TP_t^{(n)}  package’s standard form, expected short rate term computed time tt t+nt+n, represents bond’s maturity: Expt(n)=∑h=0nEt[yt+h(1)]Exp_t^{(n)} = \sum_{h=0}^{n} E_t[y_{t+h}^{(1)}]. Alternatively, one perfom decomposition forward rate level (ft(n)f_t^{(n)}), specifically ft(n)=∑h=mnEt[yt+h(1)]+FPt(n)f_t^{(n)} = \sum_{h=m}^{n} E_t[y_{t+h}^{(1)}] + FP_t^{(n)} FPt(n)FP_t^{(n)} corresponds forward premia. case, user must specify binary variable set 11 computation forward premia desired, 00 otherwise. set 11, user must also provide two-element numerical vector containing maturities corresponding starting ending dates bond maturity. Example:
code: WishFPremia <- 1 # Wish to estimate the forward premia: YES: 1, NO:0      FPmatLim <- c(60, 120)

previous_headings: Model Estimation > The P-dynamics estimation
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: GVAR() function designed estimate first-order GVAR built country-specific VARX(1,1,1) models. comprehensive discussion GVAR models, see, instance, Chudik Pesaran (2016). GVAR() function requires two key inputs: number country-specific spanned factors (N) set supplementary inputs stored GVARinputs list. former composed four elements: Economies: character vector containing names economies included system; GVAR list risk factors: list risk factors sorted country addition global variables. See outputs DatabasePrep() function; VARX type: string-vector containing desired estimated form VARX(1,1,1). Three possibilities available. “unconstrained” form estimates model without constrains, using standard OLS regressions model equation. “constrained: Spanned Factors” form prevents foreign-spanned-factors impact domestic factor feedback matrix, whereas “constrained: ’ followed name risk factor restricts factor influenced lagged values lagged values star variables. last two cases, VARX(1,1,1) estimated restricted least squares. Transition matrix: estimation GVAR model requires defining measure interdependence among countries economic system. information reported transition matrix, entries reflect degree interconnection across two entities economic system. GVAR setups can estimated using fixed , starting package’s version 0.3.30.3.3, time-varying interdependence weights. Time-varying interdependence implies star factors constructed applying trade flow weights specific year adjust risk factors corresponding year. employ feature, users need specify transition matrix type Time-varying select specific date (year) initial final years within transition matrix. implies trade weights year used solving (link matrices) GVAR system. illustration transition matrix computed average cross-border trade flow weights period spanning years 2006 2019. Therefore, degree dependence across countries assumed fixed entire sample span. Note row sums 11. defined form transition matrix, one can complete GVARinputs list estimate GVAR(1) model. Note CheckInputs parameter set TRUE perform prior consistency check inputs provided GVARinputs.
code: data('CM_Factors_GVAR') GVARinputs <- list(Economies = Economies, GVARFactors = FactorsGVAR, VARXtype ="constrained: Inflation") data("CM_Trade") t_First <- "2006" t_Last <-  "2019" Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") type <- "Sample Mean" W_gvar <- Transition_Matrix(t_First, t_Last, Economies, type, TradeFlows) print(W_gvar) ##             China    Brazil     Mexico     Uruguay ## China   0.0000000 0.6549066 0.31550095 0.029592464 ## Brazil  0.8268799 0.0000000 0.12340661 0.049713473 ## Mexico  0.8596078 0.1326284 0.00000000 0.007763753 ## Uruguay 0.3811195 0.5497525 0.06912795 0.000000000 data("CM_Factors_GVAR") GVARinputs <- list(Economies = Economies, GVARFactors = FactorsGVAR, VARXtype = "unconstrained",                     Wgvar = W_gvar) N <- 3  GVARpara <- GVAR(GVARinputs, N, CheckInputs = TRUE)

title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: Calculating PP-dynamics parameters form proposed JLL (2015) requires following inputs: () time series risk factors non-orthogonalized form; (ii) number country-specific spanned factors (iii) specification JLLinputs list, includes following elements: Economies: character vector containing names economies included system; Dominant Country: string-vector containing name economy assigned dominant country (applicable JLL original JLL joint Sigma models) None (applicable JLL DomUnit); Wish estimation sigmas matrices: binary variable assumes value equal 11 user wishes estimation JLL sigma matrices (.e. variance-covariance Cholesky factorization matrices) , 00 otherwise. Since estimation done numerically, estimation can take several minutes; Sigma non-orthogonalized variance-covariance matrix: save time, user may provide variance-covariance matrix non-orthogonalized dynamics. Otherwise, input set NULL. JLL type: string-vector containing label JLL model estimated according features described Table @ref(tab:ModFea). One possible list JLLinputs follows: , P−P-dynamics dimension JLL-based setup can computed :
code: ModelType <- "JLL original"    JLLinputs <- list(Economies = Economies, DomUnit = "China", WishSigmas = 1,  SigmaNonOrtho = NULL,                   JLLModelType = ModelType) data("CM_Factors") N <- 3 JLLpara <- JLL(RiskFactors, N, JLLinputs, CheckInputs = TRUE)

previous_headings: Model Estimation
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: ATSM estimation involves optimizing log-likelihood function optimally selecting model parameters. optimization structure package based routines term structure package Le Singleton (2018). ATSM otimization carried using Optimization() function. Broadly, unspanned risk framework JPS (2014) (, therefore, multi-country extensions) requires estimation parameter set consisting 6 elements, namely: risk-neutral long-run mean short rate (r0), risk-neutral feedback matrix (K1XQ), variance-covariance matrix (SSZ) VAR processes, standard deviation errors portfolios yields observed error (se), addition intercept (K0Z) feedback (K1Z) matrices physical dynamics. parameters K0Z K1Z estimated part model’s P−P-dynamics known closed form. Likewise, r0 se analytical solutions can factored log-likelihood function. However, remaining parameters (K1XQ SSZ) require numerical estimation. Le Singleton (2018) provide standardized routines (integrated package) set effective initial values, facilitating optimization process. MultiATSM package offers two optimization algorithms: fminunc fminsearch. default, algorithms run sequentially twice ensure model reaches global optimum. Specifically default bootstrap setup, fminunc used save time.

what: Examples of full implementation of ATSMs
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
text: section presents examples use MultiATSM package fully implement ATSMs. console displays messages help user track progress code execution step. , functions package used replicate results presented original papers JPS (2014), CM (2023) CM (2024). See Paper Replication Vignette package detailed reproduction.

previous_headings: Examples of full implementation of ATSMs
title: MultiATSM package - General Guidelines
code: ######################################################################################################## #################################### USER INPUTS ####################################################### ######################################################################################################## library(MultiATSM) # A) Load database data LoadData("CM_2024")  # B) GENERAL model inputs ModelType <- "JPS original" # available options: "JPS original", "JPS global", "GVAR single", "JPS multi",                           #"GVAR multi", "JLL original", "JLL No DomUnit", "JLL joint Sigma".  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil") # Names of the economies from the economic system GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act")# Global Variables DomVar <- c("Eco_Act") # Country-specific variables N <- 2  # Number of spanned factors per country  t0_sample <- "01-12-2007" # Format: "dd-mm-yyyy" tF_sample <- "01-12-2019" # Format: "dd-mm-yyyy"  OutputLabel <- "Test" # label of the model for saving the file DataFreq <-"Monthly" # Frequency of the data  Folder2Save <- NULL # Folder to save the required graphical outputs. NULL -> temporary directory StatQ <- 0 # Wish to impose stationary condition for the eigenvalues of each country: YES: 1,NO:0  # B.1) SPECIFIC model inputs #################################### GVAR-based models ################################################## GVARlist <- list( VARXtype = "unconstrained", W_type = "Sample Mean", t_First_Wgvar = "2005",                   t_Last_Wgvar = "2019", DataConnectedness = TradeFlows )  # VARXtype: Available options "unconstrained" or "constrained" (VARX) # W_type: Method to compute the transition matrix. Options:"Time-varying" or "Sample Mean" # t_First_Wgvar: First year of the sample (transition matrix) # t_Last_Wgvar:  Last year of the sample (transition matrix) # DataConnectedness: measure of connectedness across countries #################################### JLL-based models ################################################### JLLlist <- list(DomUnit =  "China") # DomUnit: name of the economy of the economic system, or "None" for the model "JLL No DomUnit" ###################################### BRW inputs  ###################################################### WishBC <- 0 # Wish to estimate the model with the bias correction method of BRW (2012): #YES: 1, NO:0 BRWlist <- within(list(Cent_Measure = "Mean", gamma = 0.05, N_iter = 250, B = 50, checkBRW = TRUE,                        B_check = 1000, Eigen_rest = 1),  N_burn <- round(N_iter * 0.15)) # Cent_Measure: "Mean" = compute the mean; "Median" = compute the median # gamma: Adjustment parameter # N_iter:  Number of iteration to be conserved # N_burn:  Number of iteration to be discarded # B: Number of bootstrap samples # checkBRW: wishes to perform closeness check: TRUE or FALSE # B_check: If checkBRW is chosen as TRUE, then choose number of bootstrap samples used in the check  # C) Decide on Settings for numerical outputs WishFPremia <- 1 # Wish to estimate the forward premia: YES: 1, NO:0 FPmatLim <- c(60,120) #  If the forward premia is desired, then choose the Min and max maturities of the                       # forward premia. Otherwise set NA Horiz <- 30 DesiredGraphs <- c("Fit", "IRF", "TermPremia") # "Fit", "IRF", "FEVD", "GIRF", "GFEVD", "TermPremia" WishGraphRiskFac <- 0 WishGraphYields <- 1 WishOrthoJLLgraphs <- 0  # D) Bootstrap settings WishBootstrap <- 1 #  YES: 1; No = 0. BootList <- list(methodBS = 'bs', BlockLength = 4, ndraws = 4, pctg =  95) # methodBS: bootstrap method. Available options: (i) 'bs' ; (ii) 'wild'; (iii) 'block' # BlockLength: Block length, necessary input for the block bootstrap method # ndraws: number of bootstrap draws # pctg: confidence level  # E) Out-of-sample forecast WishForecast <- 1 #  YES: 1; No = 0. ForecastList <- list(ForHoriz = 12,  t0Sample = 1, t0Forecast = 131, ForType = "Rolling") # ForHoriz: forecast horizon # t0Sample:   initial sample date # t0Forecast:  last sample date for the first forecast # ForType: Available options are "Rolling" or "Expanding"  ######################################################################################################### ## NO NEED TO MAKE CHANGES FROM HERE:  ## The sections below automatically process the inputs provided above, run the model  ## estimation, generate the numerical and graphical outputs, and save results. #########################################################################################################  # 2) Minor preliminary work: get the sets of factor labels and  a vector of common maturities FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  # 3) Prepare the inputs of the likelihood function ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0_sample, tF_sample, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacroVar, DomesticMacroVar,                            FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq, GVARlist, JLLlist, WishBC, BRWlist)  # 4) Optimization of the ATSM (Point Estimates) ModelParaList <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FactorLabels, Economies, ModelType)  # 5) Numerical and graphical outputs # a) Prepare list of inputs for graphs and numerical outputs InputsForOutputs <- InputsForOutputs(ModelType, Horiz, DesiredGraphs, OutputLabel, StatQ, DataFreq,                                     WishGraphYields, WishGraphRiskFac, WishOrthoJLLgraphs, WishFPremia,                                     FPmatLim, WishBootstrap, BootList, WishForecast, ForecastList)  # b) Fit, IRF, FEVD, GIRF, GFEVD, and Term Premia NumericalOutputs <- NumOutputs(ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels, Economies,                                   Folder2Save)  # c) Confidence intervals (bootstrap analysis) BootstrapAnalysis <- Bootstrap(ModelType, ModelParaList, NumericalOutputs, Economies, InputsForOutputs,                                FactorLabels, JLLlist, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, Folder2Save)  # 6) Out-of-sample forecasting Forecasts <- ForecastYields(ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels, Economies,                             JLLlist, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, Folder2Save)

text: NumOutputs() function returns object class ATSMNumOutputs, includes autoplot() S3S3 method. method allows users inspect empirical properties chosen specification displaying graphical outputs console, regardless whether saved Folder2Save. user must specify plot type: RiskFactors, Fit, TermPremia, one IRF, FEVD, GIRF, GFEVD (suffixed _Factors _Yields). JLL-based models, additional _Ortho suffix generates orthogonalized outputs. examples illustrate responses Brazilian Chinese yield curves global economic activity shock:   Additionally, autoplot() S3S3 method ATSMModelBoot objects—generated Bootstrap() function—allows users assess statistical significance results. example shows responses 12-month bond yields several shocks.   context, autoplot() method requires two additional inputs beyond ATSMModelBoot object. First, takes ATSMNumOutputs object provide point estimates selected output. Second, user must specify plot type, follows structure ATSMNumOutputs objects, added _Boot suffix. worth noting , example, point estimates (black lines) occasionally lie outside confidence bands. surprising, bootstrap carried draws (4).
code: GIRF_all <- autoplot(Out$NumOut, type = "GIRF_Yields") ## Warning: `aes_string()` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.0.0. ## ℹ Please use tidy evaluation idioms with `aes()`. ## ℹ See also `vignette("ggplot2-in-packages")` for more information. ## ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the MultiATSM package. ##   Please report the issue at ##   <https://github.com/rubensmoura87/MultiATSM/issues>. ## This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. ## Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was ## generated. GIRF_all$Brazil$Gl_Eco_Act GIRF_all$China$Gl_Eco_Act GIRF_all_Boot <- autoplot(Out$Bootstrap, Out$NumOut, type = "GIRF_Yields_Boot") GIRF_all_Boot$China$Y12M_China GIRF_all_Boot$Brazil$Y12M_Brazil

title: Paper Replications
text: database used replication constructed Bauer Rudebusch (2017) (BR, 2017) available Bauer’s website. paper, BR (2017) investigate whether macro-finance term structure models better suit unspanned macro risk framework JPS (2014) earlier traditional spanned settings one Ang Piazzesi (2003). Accordingly, BR (2017) intend replicate empirical results reported JPS (2014). R-code used BR (2017) also available Bauer’s website. Supported BR (2017)’s data-set, code uses MultiATSM package estimate key model parameters ATSM along lines JPS (2014). model estimation performed using JPS original modeling setup. tables compare ATSM parameter estimates generated BR (2017) MultiATSM. Overall, one can note differences estimates economically modest. QQ-dynamics parameters PP-dynamics parameters Portfolio yields errors replicability, important note P−P-dynamics results reported Table @ref(tab:PdynTab) MultiATSM package make use principal component weights provided BR (2017). matrix simply scaled-version one provided function pca_weights_one_country() package. Accordingly, despite numerical differences weight matrices, methods generate time series spanned factors perfectly correlated. Another difference two approaches relates construction form log-likelihood function (llk): BR (2017) code llk expressed terms portfolio yields, MultiATSM package generates input directly function observed yields (.e. procedures lead equivalent llk Jacobian term).
code: # A) Load database data LoadData("BR_2017")  # B) GENERAL model inputs ModelType <- "JPS original"  Economies <- c("US") # Names of the economies from the economic system GlobalVar <- c() # Global Variables DomVar <- c("GRO", "INF") # Country-specific variables N <- 3 # Number of spanned factors per country  t0_sample <- "January-1985" tF_sample <- "December-2007"  DataFreq <- "Monthly" # Frequency of the data  StatQ <- 0 # Stationary condition  ######################################################################################################### ############################### NO NEED TO MAKE CHANGES FROM HERE ####################################### ######################################################################################################### # 2) Minor preliminary work FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)   Yields <- t(BR_jps_out$Y) DomesticMacroVar <- t(BR_jps_out$M.o) GlobalMacroVar <- c()  # 3) Prepare the inputs of the likelihood function ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0_sample, tF_sample, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacroVar, DomesticMacroVar,                            FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq)  # 4) Optimization of the model ModelPara <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FactorLabels, Economies, ModelType)

title: Paper Replications
text: multi-country framework introduced Candelon Moura (2024) designed enhance tractability large-scale ATSMs, providing deeper understanding intricate global economic mechanisms underlie yield curve fluctuations. framework also reinforces statistical validity inference enhances predictive capabilities models. novel setup, embodied GVAR multi model class, benchmarked findings Jotikasthira, Le, Lundblad (2015), captured JLL original model class. paper showcases empirical illustration involving China, Brazil, Mexico, Uruguay.
code: # A) Load database data LoadData("CM_2024")  # B) GENERAL model inputs ModelType <- "GVAR multi" # Options: "GVAR multi" or "JLL original".  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act", "Gl_Inflation") DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") N <- 3  t0_sample <- "01-06-2004" tF_sample <- "01-01-2020"  OutputLabel <- "CM_jfec" DataFreq <-"Monthly" Folder2Save <- NULL  StatQ <- 0  # B.1) SPECIFIC model inputs #################################### GVAR-based models ################################################## GVARlist <- list( VARXtype = "unconstrained", W_type = "Sample Mean", t_First_Wgvar = "2004",                   t_Last_Wgvar = "2019", DataConnectedness = TradeFlows ) #################################### JLL-based models ################################################### JLLlist <- list(DomUnit =  "China") ###################################### BRW inputs  ###################################################### WishBC <- 1 BRWlist <- within(list(Cent_Measure = "Mean", gamma = 0.001, N_iter = 200, B = 50, checkBRW = TRUE,                        B_check = 1000, Eigen_rest = 1),  N_burn <- round(N_iter * 0.15))  # C) Decide on Settings for numerical outputs WishFPremia <- 1 FPmatLim <- c(24,36)  Horiz <- 25 DesiredGraphs <- c("GIRF", "GFEVD", "TermPremia") WishGraphRiskFac <- 0 WishGraphYields <- 1 WishOrthoJLLgraphs <- 1  # D) Bootstrap settings WishBootstrap <- 0 #  Set it to 1, if bootstrap is desired BootList <- list(methodBS = 'bs', BlockLength = 4, ndraws = 1000, pctg =  95)  # E) Out-of-sample forecast WishForecast <- 1 ForecastList <- list(ForHoriz = 12,  t0Sample = 1, t0Forecast = 100, ForType = "Rolling")  ######################################################################################################### ############################### NO NEED TO MAKE CHANGES FROM HERE ####################################### #########################################################################################################  # 2) Minor preliminary work: get the sets of factor labels and  a vector of common maturities FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  # 3) Prepare the inputs of the likelihood function ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0_sample, tF_sample, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacroVar, DomesticMacroVar,                            FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq, GVARlist, JLLlist, WishBC, BRWlist)  # 4) Optimization of the ATSM (Point Estimates) ModelParaList <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FactorLabels, Economies, ModelType)  # 5) Numerical and graphical outputs # a) Prepare list of inputs for graphs and numerical outputs InputsForOutputs <- InputsForOutputs(ModelType, Horiz, DesiredGraphs, OutputLabel, StatQ, DataFreq,                                     WishGraphYields, WishGraphRiskFac, WishOrthoJLLgraphs, WishFPremia,                                     FPmatLim, WishBootstrap, BootList, WishForecast, ForecastList)  # b) Fit, IRF, FEVD, GIRF, GFEVD, and Term Premia NumericalOutputs <- NumOutputs(ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels,                                 Economies, Folder2Save)  # c) Confidence intervals (bootstrap analysis) BootstrapAnalysis <- Bootstrap(ModelType, ModelParaList, NumericalOutputs, Economies, InputsForOutputs,                                FactorLabels, JLLlist, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, Folder2Save)  # 6) Out-of-sample forecasting Forecasts <- ForecastYields(ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels, Economies,                             JLLlist, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, Folder2Save)

title: Paper Replications
text: paper, Candelon Moura (2023) delve exploration underlying factors shape sovereign yield curves Brazil, India, Mexico, Russia midst COVID−19-19 pandemic crisis. comprehensively address intricate web global macro-financial particularly health-related interdependencies, study employs modeling approach based GVAR multi type framework. delving aspects, authors aim provide nuanced understanding dynamics influencing sovereign yield curves countries challenging circumstances pandemic.
code: # A) Load database data LoadData("CM_2023")  # B) GENERAL model inputs ModelType <- "GVAR multi"  Economies <- c("Brazil", "India", "Russia", "Mexico") GlobalVar <- c("US_Output_growth", "China_Output_growth", "SP500") DomVar <- c("Inflation","Output_growth", "CDS", "COVID") N <- 2  t0_sample <- "22-03-2020" tF_sample <- "26-09-2021"  OutputLabel <- "CM_EM" DataFreq <-"Weekly" F2S <- NULL  StatQ <- 0  # B.1) SPECIFIC model inputs #################################### GVAR-based models ################################################## GVARlist <- list( VARXtype = "constrained: COVID", W_type = "Sample Mean", t_First_Wgvar = "2015",                   t_Last_Wgvar = "2020", DataConnectedness = Trade_Flows) ###################################### BRW inputs  ###################################################### WishBC <- 0  # C) Decide on Settings for numerical outputs WishFPremia <- 1 FPmatLim <- c(47,48)  Horiz <- 12 DesiredGraphs <- c("GIRF", "GFEVD", "TermPremia") WishGraphRiskFac <- 0 WishGraphYields <- 1 WishOrthoJLLgraphs <- 0  # D) Bootstrap settings WishBootstrap <- 1 #  YES: 1; No = 0. BootList <- list(methodBS = 'bs', BlockLength = 4, ndraws = 100, pctg =  95)  ######################################################################################################### ############################### NO NEED TO MAKE CHANGES FROM HERE ####################################### #########################################################################################################  # 2) Minor preliminary work: get the sets of factor labels and  a vector of common maturities FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  # 3) Prepare the inputs of the likelihood function ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0_sample, tF_sample, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacro, DomMacro, FactorLabels,                            Economies, DataFreq, GVARlist)  # 4) Optimization of the ATSM (Point Estimates) ModelParaList <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FactorLabels, Economies, ModelType)  # 5) Numerical and graphical outputs # a) Prepare list of inputs for graphs and numerical outputs InputsForOutputs <- InputsForOutputs(ModelType, Horiz, DesiredGraphs, OutputLabel, StatQ, DataFreq,                                     WishGraphYields, WishGraphRiskFac, WishOrthoJLLgraphs, WishFPremia,                                     FPmatLim, WishBootstrap, BootList)  # b) Fit, IRF, FEVD, GIRF, GFEVD, and Term Premia NumericalOutputs <- NumOutputs(ModelType, ModelParaList, InputsForOutputs, FactorLabels,                                 Economies, F2S)  # c) Confidence intervals (bootstrap analysis) BootstrapAnalysis <- Bootstrap(ModelType, ModelParaList, NumericalOutputs, Economies, InputsForOutputs,                                FactorLabels, JLLlist = NULL, GVARlist, WishBC, BRWlist, F2S)

title: Estimates an unbiased VAR(1) using stochastic approximation (Bauer, Rudebusch and Wu, 2012) — Bias_Correc_VAR
text: ModelType character vector indicating model type estimated. BRWinputs list containing necessary inputs BRW model estimation: Cent_Measure: Determines whether "Mean" "Median"-unbiased estimation desired. gamma: Numeric. Adjustment parameter 0 1. Default 0.5. N_iter: Integer. Number iterations stochastic approximation algorithm burn-. Default 5,000. N_burn: Integer. Number burn-iterations. Default 15 B: Integer. Number bootstrap samples per iteration calculating noisy measure biased estimator's mean median. Default 50. check: Logical. Indicates whether perform closeness check. Default TRUE. B_check: Integer. Number bootstrap samples closeness check. Default 100,000. Eigen_rest: Numeric. Restriction largest eigenvalue P-measure. Default 1. RiskFactors numeric matrix (T x F) representing time series risk factors. Economies character vector containing names economies included system. FactorLabels list character vectors labels variables model. GVARinputs List. Inputs GVAR model estimation (see GVAR function). Default NULL. JLLinputs List. Inputs JLL model estimation (see JLL function). Default NULL. verbose verbose Logical flag controlling function messaging. Default TRUE.

title: Estimates an unbiased VAR(1) using stochastic approximation (Bauer, Rudebusch and Wu, 2012) — Bias_Correc_VAR
text: Bias-corrected VAR parameters based framework Bauer, Rudebusch Wu (2012). list contains: KOZ_BC: estimated intercept (F x 1); K1Z_BC: estimated feedback matrix (F x F); SSZ_BC: estimated variance-covariance matrix (F x F); dist: root mean square distance (scalar);

title: Estimates an unbiased VAR(1) using stochastic approximation (Bauer, Rudebusch and Wu, 2012) — Bias_Correc_VAR
text: Bauer, Rudebusch , Wu (2012). "Correcting Estimation Bias Dynamic Term Structure Models"  R implementation inspired methodology described therein. Related Matlab routines available Cynthia Wu's website (https://sites.google.com/view/jingcynthiawu/).

title: Estimates an unbiased VAR(1) using stochastic approximation (Bauer, Rudebusch and Wu, 2012) — Bias_Correc_VAR
code: # \donttest{ data(CM_Factors) Factors <- t(RiskFactors[1:7,])  BRWinputs <- list(Cent_Measure = "Mean", gamma = 0.4, N_iter = 1000, N_burn = 100,                   B = 10, check = 1, B_check = 5000)  Economies <- "China" N <- 3 ModelType <- "JPS original" FactorLabels <- NULL  BRWpara <- Bias_Correc_VAR(ModelType, BRWinputs, Factors, Economies, FactorLabels) #> iteration:  100  /  1099 #> iteration:  200  /  1099 #> iteration:  300  /  1099 #> iteration:  400  /  1099 #> iteration:  500  /  1099 #> iteration:  600  /  1099 #> iteration:  700  /  1099 #> iteration:  800  /  1099 #> iteration:  900  /  1099 #> iteration:  1000  /  1099 #> Root mean square distance:  0.048839 #> ... Done!  # }

code: DataForEstimation(   t0,   tF,   Economies,   N,   FactorLabels,   ModelType,   DataFrequency,   Macro_FullData,   Yields_FullData,   DataConnect = NULL,   W_type = NULL,   t_First_Wgvar = NULL,   t_Last_Wgvar = NULL )

title: Retrieves data from Excel and build the database used in the model estimation — DataForEstimation
text: t0 Start date sample period format yyyy-mm-dd. Day form must "01" tF End date sample period format yyyy-mm-dd. Day form must "01". Economies character vector containing names economies included system. N Integer. Number country-specific spanned factors. FactorLabels String-list based contains labels variables present model ModelType String-vector containing label model estimated DataFrequency Character-based-vector. Available options : "Daily Days", "Daily Business Days", "Weekly", "Monthly", "Quarterly", "Annually" Macro_FullData List containing full set macroeconomic data. Yields_FullData List containing full set bond yield data DataConnect List containing data computing bilateral contentedness measures. Default NULL. W_type Three possibilities: Full Sample: one wishes weight matrices year data available (may extrapolate sample period); Sample Mean: one wishes SINGLE weight matrix containing average weights entire sample period; year particular (e.g. "1998", "2005" ...). t_First_Wgvar Sample starting date (year) t_Last_Wgvar Sample last date (year)

title: Retrieves data from Excel and build the database used in the model estimation — DataForEstimation
text: list containing time series complete set bond yields (matrix, J x T CJ x T); time series complete set risk factors (matrix, K x T); 'GVARFactors': list variables used estimation VARX                 (see e.g. CM_Factors_GVAR file). estimated model type GVAR-based, returns NULL.

title: Retrieves data from Excel and build the database used in the model estimation — DataForEstimation
code: DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation")  GlobalVar <- c("GBC", "CPI_OECD")  t0 <- "2006-09-01"  tF <-  "2019-01-01"  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay", "Russia")  N <- 2  ModelType <- "JPS original"  FactorLabels <-  LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  DataFrequency <- "Monthly"  #  Retrieve data from excel files MacroData  <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "MacroData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) YieldData <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "YieldsData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM"))   DataModel <- DataForEstimation(t0, tF, Economies, N, FactorLabels, ModelType, DataFrequency,                                 MacroData, YieldData)

title: Gather data of several countries in a list. Particularly useful for GVAR-based setups (Compute
code: # Load data from excel macro_data  <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "MacroData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) yields_data <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "YieldsData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) trade_data  <- Load_Excel_Data(system.file("extdata", "TradeData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")) #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1` #> New names: #> • `` -> `...1`  # Adjust trade data trade_data <- lapply(trade_data, function(df) {  countries <- df[[1]]  df <- as.data.frame(df[-1])  rownames(df) <- countries  df })  # Define features of interest ModelType <- "GVAR multi" Economies <- c("China", "Uruguay", "Russia") GlobalVar <- c("GBC", "CPI_OECD") DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") N <- 3 t0 <- "2006-09-01" tF <- "2019-01-01"   # Compute some inputs FactorLabels <-  LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType) Wgvar <- Transition_Matrix(t_First = "2006", t_Last= "2019", Economies,                           type = "Sample Mean", trade_data)  # Compute GVARFactors GVARFactors <- DatabasePrep(t0, tF, Economies, N, FactorLabels, ModelType, macro_data,                            yields_data, Wgvar)

title: Estimates a GVAR(1) and a VARX(1,1,1) models — GVAR
text: GVARinputs List inputs GVAR model estimation: Economies:  character vector containing names economies included system. GVARFactors: list variables used estimation VARX model                 (see e.g. CM_Factors_GVAR file details); VARXtype: character vector three possible options: 'unconstrained': model estimated without constraints (equation estimated individually ordinary least square); 'constrained: Spanned Factors': model estimated restriction foreign pricing factors                                affect () domestic economic variables (ii) domestic pricing factors.                                (Equations estimated using restricted least squares) 'constrained : [factor_name]': model estimated restriction specified risk factor              influenced lagged values lagged values corresponding star variables.        (Equations estimated using restricted least squares.) Wgvar: GVAR transition matrix (C x C) used model solution.                                 (See output Transition_Matrix function.). N Integer. Number country-specific spanned factors. CheckInputs logical flag indicate whether perform prior consistency check inputs provided GVARinputs. default set FALSE

code: InputsForOpt(   InitialSampleDate,   FinalSampleDate,   ModelType,   Yields,   GlobalMacro,   DomMacro,   FactorLabels,   Economies,   DataFrequency,   GVARlist = NULL,   JLLlist = NULL,   WishBRW = FALSE,   BRWlist = NULL,   UnitYields = "Month",   CheckInputs = TRUE,   BS_Adj = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Generates inputs necessary to build the likelihood function for the ATSM model — InputsForOpt
text: InitialSampleDate Start date sample period format "dd-mm-yyyy" FinalSampleDate End date sample period format "dd-mm-yyyy" ModelType character vector indicating model type estimated. Available options: "JPS original", "JPS global", "GVAR single", "JPS multi", "GVAR multi", "JLL original", "JLL DomUnit", "JLL joint Sigma". Yields numerical matrix time series yields (J x T CJ x T) GlobalMacro numerical matrix time series global risk factors (G x T) DomMacro numerical matrix time series country-specific risk factors C countries (CM x T) FactorLabels list character vectors labels variables model. Economies character vector containing names economies included system. DataFrequency character vector specifying frequency data. Available options : "Daily Days", "Daily Business Days", "Weekly", "Monthly", "Quarterly", "Annually". GVARlist list containing necessary inputs estimation GVAR-based models JLLlist list necessary inputs estimation JLL-based models. chosen model "JLL original" "JLL joint Sigma", dominant unit economy must chosen. Otherwise, list must set 'None'. WishBRW Logical. Whether estimate physical parameter model bias correction, based method Bauer, Rudebusch Wu (2012). Default FALSE. BRWlist List necessary inputs performing bias-corrected estimation. UnitYields character string indicating maturity unit yields. Options : "Month" yields expressed months, "Year" yields expressed years. Default "Month". CheckInputs Logical. Whether perform prior check consistency provided input list. Default TRUE. BS_Adj Logical. Whether adjust global series sepQ models Bootstrap setting. Default FALSE. verbose Logical flag controlling function messaging. Default TRUE.

title: Generates inputs necessary to build the likelihood function for the ATSM model — InputsForOpt
text: object class 'ATSMModelInputs' containing necessary inputs performing model optimization.

title: Generates inputs necessary to build the likelihood function for the ATSM model — InputsForOpt
text: - `print(object)` - `summary(object)`

title: Generates inputs necessary to build the likelihood function for the ATSM model — InputsForOpt
code: # \donttest{ # Example 1: data(CM_GlobalMacroFactors) data(CM_DomMacroFactors) data(CM_Yields)  ModelType <- "JPS original" Economies <- "Mexico" t0 <- "01-05-2007" # Initial Sample Date (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") tF <- "01-12-2018" # Final Sample Date (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") N <- 3 GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act") # Global Variables DomVar <- c("Eco_Act") # Domestic Variables FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  DataFreq <- "Monthly"  ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0, tF, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacroVar, DomesticMacroVar,                              FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq, CheckInputs = FALSE) #> 1) PREPARING INPUTS FOR THE ESTIMATION OF THE MODEL: JPS original . SAMPLE PERIOD: 01-05-2007 - 01-12-2018 #> 1.1) Constructing the time-series of the risk factors #> 1.2) Estimating model P-dynamics parameters: #> - Without the bias-correction procedure   # Example 2: LoadData("CM_2024")  ModelType <- "GVAR multi"  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") t0 <- "01-05-2007" # InitialSampleDate (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") tF <- "01-12-2019" # FinalSampleDate (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") N <- 2 GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act", "Gl_Inflation") # Global Variables DomVar <- c("Inflation") # Domestic Variables FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  DataFreq <- "Monthly" GVARlist <- list(VARXtype = "unconstrained", W_type = "Sample Mean",                  t_First_Wgvar = "2007", t_Last_Wgvar = "2019", DataConnectedness = TradeFlows)  ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0, tF, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacroVar, DomesticMacroVar,                            FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq, GVARlist, CheckInputs = FALSE) #> 1) PREPARING INPUTS FOR THE ESTIMATION OF THE MODEL: GVAR multi . SAMPLE PERIOD: 01-05-2007 - 01-12-2019 #> 1.1) Constructing the time-series of the risk factors #> 1.2) Estimating model P-dynamics parameters: #> - Without the bias-correction procedure   # Example 3: if (requireNamespace('neldermead', quietly = TRUE)) { LoadData("CM_2024")  ModelType <- "JLL original"  Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Uruguay") t0 <- "01-05-2007" # InitialSampleDate (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") tF <- "01-12-2019" # FinalSampleDate (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") N <- 2 GlobalVar <- c("Gl_Eco_Act", "Gl_Inflation") # Global Variables DomVar <- c("Eco_Act", "Inflation") # Domestic Variables FactorLabels <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economies, ModelType)  JLLinputs <- list(DomUnit = "China")  DataFrequency <- "Monthly"  ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0, tF, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacroVar, DomesticMacroVar,                            FactorLabels, Economies, DataFreq, JLLlist = JLLinputs,                            CheckInputs = FALSE) } else {  message("skipping functionality due to missing Suggested dependency") } #> 1) PREPARING INPUTS FOR THE ESTIMATION OF THE MODEL: JLL original . SAMPLE PERIOD: 01-05-2007 - 01-12-2019 #> 1.1) Constructing the time-series of the risk factors #> 1.2) Estimating model P-dynamics parameters: #> - Without the bias-correction procedure  #> JLL-based setup in progress: Estimating the variance-covariance matrix numerically. #>                              This may take some time.  # }

title: Collects the inputs that are used to construct the numerical and the graphical outputs — InputsForOutputs
code: InputsForOutputs(   ModelType,   Horiz,   ListOutputWished,   OutputLabel,   WishStationarityQ,   DataFrequency,   WishGraphYields = 0,   WishGraphRiskFactors = 0,   WishOrthoJLLgraphs = 0,   WishForwardPremia = 0,   LimFP = NULL,   WishBootstrap = 0,   ListBoot = NULL,   WishForecast = 0,   ListForecast = NULL,   UnitYields = "Month" )

title: Collects the inputs that are used to construct the numerical and the graphical outputs — InputsForOutputs
text: ModelType character vector indicating model type estimated. Horiz numeric scalar specifying desired analysis horizon outputs. ListOutputWished list desired graphical outputs. Available options : "Fit", "IRF", "FEVD", "GIRF", "GFEVD", "TermPremia". OutputLabel string name output label stored. WishStationarityQ binary variable (1 0) indicating whether impose largest eigenvalue Q strictly smaller 1. Set 1 impose restriction, 0 otherwise. DataFrequency character vector specifying data frequency. Available options: "Daily Days", "Daily Business Days", "Weekly", "Monthly", "Quarterly", "Annually". WishGraphYields binary variable (1 0) indicating whether user wishes generate graphs yields. Default 0. WishGraphRiskFactors binary variable (1 0) indicating whether user wishes generate graphs risk factors. Default 0. WishOrthoJLLgraphs binary variable (1 0) indicating whether user wishes generate orthogonalized JLL-based graphs. Default 0. WishForwardPremia binary variable (1 0) indicating whether user wishes generate forward premia graphs. Default 0. LimFP numeric vector containing maturities associated start end dates loan. WishBootstrap binary variable (1 0) indicating whether user wishes perform bootstrap-based estimation. Default 0. ListBoot List containing following four elements: methodBS: Desired bootstrap method: () 'bs' standard residual bootstrap, (b) 'wild' wild bootstrap,                    (c) 'block' block bootstrap. BlockLength: block bootstrap chosen, specify block length (numeric scalar). ndraws: Number bootstrap draws. pctg: Confidence level expressed basis points (numeric vector). WishForecast binary variable (1 0) indicating whether user wishes generate forecasts. Default 0. ListForecast list containing following three elements: ForHoriz: forecast horizon; t0Sample: Index first variable information set. t0Forecast: Index first forecast cut-date. ForType: string specifying desired forecast type. Available options : "Rolling" "Expanding". UnitYields character string indicating maturity unit yields. Options : () "Month" yields expressed months, (ii) "Year" yields expressed years. Default "Month".

code: MLEdensity(   K1XQ,   r0,   SSZ,   K0Z,   K1Z,   se,   Gy.0,   mat,   Y,   Z,   P,   Wpca,   We,   WpcaFull,   dt,   Economies,   FactorLabels,   ModelType,   GVARinputs = NULL,   JLLinputs = NULL,   BS_outputs = FALSE,   nargout )

title: Compute the maximum likelihood function of all models — MLEdensity
text: K1XQ risk-neutral feedback matrix (N x N CN x CN) r0 long-run interest rate (scalar vector length C) SSZ variance-covariance matrix (F x F) K0Z intercept P-dynamics (F x 1) K1Z feedback matrix P-dynamics (F x F) se Variance portfolio yields observed error (scalar). Default set NULL. Gy.0 matrix contemporaneous terms P-dynamics (F x F) mat vector maturities (years) yields used estimation (J x 1) Y matrix yields used estimation (J x T CJ x T) Z complete set spanned unspanned factors (F x T) P complete set spanned factors (N x T CN x T) Wpca matrix weights portfolios observed without errors (N x J CN x J) matrix weights portfolios observed errors ((J-N) x J C(J-N) x CJ) WpcaFull composite matrix weights portfolios observed without errors dt time interval unit model (scalar). instance, data () monthly, dt <- 12; (ii) quarterly, dt <- 4; (iii) yearly, dt <- 1. Economies string-vector containing names economies part economic system FactorLabels string-list based contains labels variables present model ModelType string-vector containing label model estimated GVARinputs model chosen "GVAR single" "GVAR multi", "GVARinputs" specified (see "GVAR" function) JLLinputs model chosen JLL-based. "JLLinputs" contain () DomUnit, (ii) WishSigmas, (iii) SigmaNonOrtho, (iv) JLLModelType (See JLL function) BS_outputs Generates simplified output list bootstrap setting. Default set FALSE. nargout nargout == 1: provides values likelihood; nargout == 2: complete ATSM outputs

title: Perform the optimization of the log-likelihood function of the chosen ATSM — Optimization

title: Perform the optimization of the log-likelihood function of the chosen ATSM — Optimization
code: LoadData("CM_2024") ModelType <- "JPS original" Economy <- "Brazil" t0 <- "01-05-2007" # Initial Sample Date (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") tF <- "01-12-2018" # Final Sample Date (Format: "dd-mm-yyyy") N <- 1 GlobalVar <- "Gl_Eco_Act" # Global Variables DomVar <- "Eco_Act" # Domestic Variables DataFreq <- "Monthly" StatQ <- 0  FacLab <- LabFac(N, DomVar, GlobalVar, Economy, ModelType) ATSMInputs <- InputsForOpt(t0, tF, ModelType, Yields, GlobalMacroVar, DomesticMacroVar,                            FacLab, Economy, DataFreq, CheckInputs = FALSE) #> 1) PREPARING INPUTS FOR THE ESTIMATION OF THE MODEL: JPS original . SAMPLE PERIOD: 01-05-2007 - 01-12-2018 #> 1.1) Constructing the time-series of the risk factors #> 1.2) Estimating model P-dynamics parameters: #> - Without the bias-correction procedure   OptPara <- Optimization(ATSMInputs, StatQ, DataFreq, FacLab, Economy, ModelType) #> 2) ATSM ESTIMATION : POINT ESTIMATE ANALYSIS #> 2.1) Estimating ATSM ... #>  ... for country: Brazil . This may take several minutes. #>    *** Estimation round 1 completed *** #>    *** Estimation round 2 completed *** #> -- Done! #> Elapsed time: 2.66 seconds

title: Perform the minimization of mean(f) — Optimization_PE
text: f vector-valued objective function (function) ListInputSet list contain starting values constraints:                        input argument K (f), need four inputs look like: starting value: K0 variable label ('K0') followed ':' followed type constraint. constraint can : 'bounded': bounded matrix; 'Jordan' 'Jordan MultiCountry': matrix Jordan type; 'psd': psd matrix; 'stationary': largest eigenvalue risk-neutral feedback matrix strictly smaller 1; 'diag' 'BlockDiag': diagonal block diagonal matrix. 'JLLstructure': impose zero-restrictions variance-variance matrix along                              lines JLL models lower bound lb (lb <- NULL -> lower bound) upper bound ub (ub <- NULL -> upper bound) Specification optimization settings: 'iter ': hide printouts numerical optimization routines; 'fminunc ': uses fminunc optimization; ”fminsearch ': uses fminsearch optimization. FactorLabels list character vectors labels variables model. Economies character vector containing names economies included system. ModelType character vector indicating model type estimated. JLLinputs List. Inputs JLL model estimation (see JLL). Default NULL. GVARinputs List. Inputs GVAR model estimation (see GVAR). Default NULL. tol convergence tolerance (scalar). Default value 1e-4. TimeCount computes required time estimation model. Default TRUE. verbose Logical flag controlling function messaging.

title: Perform the minimization of mean(f) — Optimization_PE
text: function conceptually based "LS__opt" function Le Singleton (2018).   "Small Package Matlab Routines Estimation Term Structure Models."   (Euro Area Business Cycle Network Training School - Term Structure Modelling).  Available : https://cepr.org/40029

title: Concatenate the model-specific inputs in a list — SpecificMLEInputs
text: ModelType string-vector containing label model estimated Economies string-vector containing names economies system RiskFactors time series risk factors (F x T) FactorLabels string-list based contains labels variables present model GVARlist list required inputs estimate GVAR-based setups: VARXtype  string-vector containing VARX feature (see "GVAR" function) (GVAR-based models) t_First_Wgvar Sample starting date (year) (GVAR-based models) t_Last_Wgvar  Sample last date (year) (GVAR-based models) W_type  Criterion used computation star variables (see "Transition_Matrix" function)               (GVAR-based models) JLLlist list required inputs estimate JLL-based setups: DomUnit name economy assigned dominant unit (JLL-based models) WishSigmas equal "1" one wishes variance-covariance matrices Cholesky factorizations (JLL-based models) SigmaNonOrtho NULL F x F matrix non-orthogonalized dynamics (JLL-based models) WishBRW Whether user wishes estimate physical parameter model Bias correction model BRW (2012) (see "Bias_Correc_VAR" function). Default set 0. BRWlist list required inputs estimate bias corrected setups type BRW: BiasCorrection binary variable. takes value equal 1 user whishes estimates bias-corrected                      0, otherwise. (BRW model) flag_mean flag whether mean- (TRUE) median- (FALSE) unbiased estimation desired gamma adjustment parameter (BRW model) N_iter number iterations (BRW model) N_burn number burn-iterations (BRW model) B  number bootstrap samples (BRW model) checkBRW flag whether user wishes perform closeness check (BRW model) B_check number bootstrap samples closeness check

title: Computes the transition matrix required in the estimation of the GVAR model — Transition_Matrix
text: t_First Sample starting date (format: yyyy). t_Last Sample ending date (format: yyyy). Economies character vector containing names economies included system. type character string indicating method computing interdependence. Possible options include: Time-varying: Computes time-varying interdependence returns weight matrices year based available data (may extrapolate sample period). Sample Mean: Returns single weight matrix containing average weights entire sample period, suitable time-invariant interdependence. specific year (e.g., "1998", "2005"): Used compute time-invariant interdependence specified year. DataConnectedness Data used compute transition matrix.

code: t_First <- "2006" t_Last <-  "2019" Economies <- c("China", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Uruguay") type <- "Sample Mean" GetExcelData <- FALSE   if (GetExcelData) {  if (!requireNamespace("readxl", quietly = TRUE)) {  stop(    "Please install package \"readxl\" to use this feature.",    call. = FALSE  )    DataPath <- system.file("extdata", "TradeData.xlsx", package = "MultiATSM")    tab_names_Trade <- readxl::excel_sheets(DataPath)    list_all_Trade <- suppressMessages(lapply(tab_names_Trade, function(x)                      readxl::read_excel(path = DataPath, sheet = x)))    names(list_all_Trade) <- tab_names_Trade     L <- length(list_all_Trade)     for (i in 1:L) {      Countries <- list_all_Trade[[i]][[1]]      list_all_Trade[[i]] <- as.data.frame(list_all_Trade[[i]][,-1])      rownames(list_all_Trade[[i]]) <- Countries    }     DataConnectedness <- list_all_Trade  } } else {  data(CM_Trade)  DataConnectedness <- TradeFlows }  W_mat <- Transition_Matrix(t_First, t_Last, Economies, type, DataConnectedness)
